They see limitations set on the expansion of non-government schools with growing government intrusion and interference. They see total confusion in the administration and design of the various year 12 examinations in the States. They then see thousands of young people disappointed when they gain good marks in their Higher School Certificate examinations, or the equivalent, but are turned away from universities, CAEs and TAFE colleges because there are too few places for them. For those who manage to gain a place in higher education, they then see some lack of relevance to the realities of the modern work place.

People see crumbling buildings, over-crowded lecture theatres, machines and equipment that are outdated and beyond repair, libraries which can no longer afford the up-to-date texts and journals, and growing morale problems in the academic community. They also see students living in conditions of poverty because of the Government's mishand- ling of the Austudy scheme, with payments in some cases up to four months late.

I am sure everyone in this Parliament is familiar with these problems because of experiences in their own electorate and State. As shadow Minister for Education I travel around the country, and in all cities and towns I find growing alarm at the state of our schools and tertiary institutions. No matter whether one speaks to principals and teachers, parents and students, business groups and employers, the message is clear: Education has some major problems.

The Labor Government is presiding over an education system in turmoil. The response of this Government to the problems of education has in general been blinkered, limited and haphazard. The only constant theme in this Government's education decisions is its increasing interference and control-which not only fails to address the central concerns in education but restricts the ability of schools and institutions to grow and expand to meet different needs.

These three States grants Bills before us today mainly provide additional grants to the States and the Northern Territory to effectively index existing grants to take into account movements in prices and costs. These education packages come through this Parliament twice each year-the main grants come after the Budget and are legislated for in October or November, then around April or May in the following year we consider the cost supplementation packages, such as this set of Bills today.

The Liberal Party does not oppose these Bills although I foreshadow that we will be moving two amendments to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill-one in-principle amendment at the second reading stage and one more detailed amendment to a clause of the Bill during the Committee consideration. I will deal with the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill first. This Bill includes a major change in the administration of the capital grants program for non-government schools. The Commonwealth Government has provided grants for capital facilities in various forms since 1964. This year the Commonwealth will provide some $210m in capital grants, $56m of this to non-government schools.

This year, as in previous years, capital grant allocations are made on the recommendations of planning and finance committees established in each State. The committees combine nominees of Catholic systems, non-systemic schools, State and Federal education departments and the Commonwealth Minister for Education. Within the guidelines the committees sift the applications and determine funding priorities which are, almost without exception, accepted by the Minister. The actual administration of the capital grants to schools and systems is the responsibility of the Department of Education following the 1985 transfer of this function from the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The Auditor-General's efficiency audit report strongly criticised many aspects of the Commonwealth Schools Commission's administration of the capital program. There were serious deficiencies in the processing, assessment and approval of grant applications. The Commission, according to the Auditor-General's report, failed to provide adequate information to grant applicants, failed to issue clear and comprehensive guidelines for the program and its administration, and failed to protect the Commonwealth's financial interest.

The Department of Education is now responsible for the capital grants program and the Government is dragging its heels in addressing the implications in the Auditor-General's report. The First Assistant Auditor-General, Mr Jim O'Neil, told the Joint Committee of Public Accounts last week that the Department had so far dealt with only five of the 70 problems identified in the audit, including such basic issues as whether the annual program guidelines might be issued earlier. There has been total confusion and inconsistency in the capital grants program under this Government. There have been numerous major changes in the grants policy since 1983, and even this year it has been necessary to continue the process of policy by Press release to address growing problems. Since 1983, the program has been administered first by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, as I have said, and now by the Department of Education. If this legislation is passed, it will be administered by block grant authorities of the non-government school sector. That will be the third major change in five years.

Under this legislation it is proposed that from 1988 capital grants for non-government schools will be allocated as a block grant for internal distribution by authorities set up for that purpose. In announcing this change on 4 February this year, the Minister for Education said that it was expected that in most States Catholic schools would form one block authority and most other non-government schools a second authority. The Minister stated that schools not electing to join an authority would still be able to apply directly to the Commonwealth. As a first principle I am always attracted to a decentralising of power, to restoring local decision making, which is more sensitive to the variety of needs in different parts of Australia. It seems sensible and reasonable wherever possible to pay block payments of capital grants to school systems in the same way that recurrent grants are distributed. However, I am concerned that details of this new scheme are not yet available. Indeed, the most that non-government school authorities have seen to date is a vague preliminary interim draft, to use the current jargon.

There are several potential dangers in this proposal. First, there may be an attempt to switch the responsibility for the Commonwealth's equity in school capital projects from the Department of Education to the block grant authorities. By way of background, when the Commonwealth provides funds for a non-government school capital project, there is a continuing financial interest over 20 years, with the value of that equity reduced by 5 per cent a year. Non-government schools can be required to repay this equity to the Commonwealth in certain circumstances; for example, if the school closes down. As the Auditor-General noted in his report, the Commonwealth's equity in school projects has been poorly protected by present arrangements. He referred to a Schools Commission estimate that in 1984 there were some 200 to 300 schools that had received major capital grants but then subsequently closed, changed location or were operating under a different authority, most of which had not met the legislative requirements applying to the disposal of assets acquired with grant moneys. The audit revealed staggering mismanagement and inefficiency within the Schools Commission in regard to the capital grants process. The administration now rests with the Department of Education but there are no figures available to say whether the situation has improved at all.

I think that there is a real danger in this proposal that the Government is going to try to get off the hook and make the block grant authorities directly responsible for the Commonwealth's equity interest. In other words, my concern is that the Government could seek to shirk its duty to maintain its own equity, and transfer the legal responsibility to the corporate bodies which will receive the block grant and distribute it to schools within their associations. The block grant authority would then become directly liable to repay the Commonwealth's equity if a member school breached the legislation and agreements covering the grant. This is especially a threat in the case of independent schools, which are not in any sense owned, controlled or directed by the voluntary associations which have been formed to provide a common forum and voice. Organisations such as the National Council of Independent Schools have no direct powers over their member schools yet, as one of the likely non-systemic authorities which will form to allocate capital grants, such an authority could be made liable for future actions of its member schools. This would be an outrage and would threaten the fundamental nature of these voluntary associations.

Let me make this point clear: The equity interest belongs to the Commonwealth. If the Commonwealth wants its equity protected, and it must, on behalf of Australian taxpayers, then it should accept the responsibility and get its own house in order. Independent school bodies have enough to do without riding shotgun and playing debt collector for a government which cannot do its own job properly. The Liberal Party will be looking closely at the guidelines which will implement and accompany this arrangement.

We are also disturbed that the legislation is completely silent on the costs to non-government agencies of administering the capital grants. I understand that the Government plans to permit administration to absorb 2 per cent of the block grant, up to a limit of $35,000. This will be completely inadequate to cover the cost of this process. Organisations such as the NCIS will probably have to charge their members an additional levy to meet the cost of this capital grant process. The great irony here is that many of the member schools which will be paying higher levies to finance this new responsibility are themselves ineligible for capital grants under the present restrictive guidelines. In other words, block grant authorities could end up significantly out of pocket-yet another move to cut back the resources they can devote to the real tasks of education.

The Government has not established a case for the introduction of this block grant process. There are no significant complaints about the present arrangements through State planning and finance committees, at least not from systemic and independent school authorities. The measures proposed will substantially increase the administrative burden on non-government school authorities, increasing their costs and diverting staff resources away from other priorities. A senior official from the Department of Education told the Public Accounts Committee last week that she thought the new system would be equally accountable as the present arrangements-not more accountable, mind you, but simply equally accountable. So there is no genuine case to support this change.

I turn now to a specific clause in the legislation which I shall seek to have deleted in the Committee stage. Clause 8 of the Bill seeks to extend the Minister's powers in the proposed section 25b, sub-section (4). This would give the Minister power to refuse a grant recommended by block authorities in certain circumstances: First, if a co-educational school has applied for a capital grant and the Minister thinks the benefits may not be equally beneficial to both male and female students; and secondly, if the project is mainly or partially designed to provide staff accommodation or facilities used in relation to religious worship. This sub-section permits the Minister to intrude still further into the legitimate decision-making responsibilities of schools and systems, and is yet another window of opportunity for the bureaucracy to exert control over independent schools.

I also note that government schools are allowed to spend capital funds on the provision of teachers housing in areas outside capital cities. There appears to be a discriminatory distinction concerning non-government schools in this regard. If the Government is determined to limit the non-government sector's use of capital grants, in my view it should set these matters down in the guidelines to block authorities rather than enshrine them in legislation-legislation without guidelines and which may be subject to the whim of the Minister.

I now turn to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill which supplements, due to cost increases, existing grants for universities, colleges of advanced education, institutes of technology and technical and further education colleges. This is a straightforward measure, which we will not oppose. I do, however, wish to refer briefly to the anomalous $250 administration charge which the Government introduced this year. When debating the legislation for the administration charge last October, I predicted that the charge would deter many part time and external students and probably lead to a reduction in the total number of students. I also stated the Opposition's concern that institutions would incur administrative costs which would not be covered by the windfall $25 they were to retain from each student and that the charge would undermine the Government's $200,000 campaign to increase rural participation in higher education.

The report to the Minister from the Higher Education Monitoring Committee-better known as the HEAC Monitoring Committee-makes it clear that these predictions have been proven true. There has been an overall decline in student numbers of one per cent. A marginal rise in full time enrolments has been offset by a fall of 9.6 per cent in part time enrolments and a fall of 8.1 per cent in external enrolments. So much for a commitment to participation. In 1987 there are 3,700 fewer students in higher education than last year. I welcome the Committee's recommendation that the charge be set in future on a pro rata basis so that, over the duration of a course, part time students pay the same total amount as a full time student making comparable academic progress. This was the most glaring flaw in the original design of the charge and it is astounding that the Government was blind to the problems it would cause. The Liberal Party sincerely hopes that Senator Ryan will now take action to remedy this situation. The Monitoring Committee's report also put paid to the lie that institutions would benefit financially from the charge. The report states:

The additional costs incurred in collecting the charge included costs associated with the employment of additional staff for both collection and financial counselling . . . other administrative costs mentioned included extra computing time, postage and security for the large amounts of money collected.

So much for the Government's promise of a pot of gold at the end of the administration charge rainbow! Institutions have lost out again. I also note that external rural students as a group have been adversely affected by the charge which, as predicted, makes a mockery of the Government's famous rural strategy promise to extend educational access for rural communities. The Monitoring Committee has recommended that the list of exempt students be widened next year to include a broader basket of disadvantaged students. The Opposition awaits with interest the Government's response. Of course, the Government is committed to a rise in the charge to some $270 at least in 1988 and has yet to deal with the reported moves to increase the charge next year to $500 a student. The May economic statement, or perhaps the Budget, we presume, will reveal all.

The final Bill in this package being considered today, the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill, is also straightforward and will not be opposed. This Bill is, of course, the participation and equity program's swan-song. The program is planned to end this year, and the Schools Commission is developing a new specific purpose program in the wake of its report on secondary education. We on this side of the House have consistently voiced concern about the administration of the PEP scheme. I imagine that I will have time after lunch when we resume this debate to say a little more about that. At this point I conclude by saying that it has misplaced priorities and it has dubious educational value. It is interesting to find that the Schools Commission's assessment of PEP echoes our complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being almost 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The honourable member for Tangney will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed at a later hour.

—I inform the House that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is absent from Question Time today on official business, and any questions normally directed to him should be directed to the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins).

—I ask the Prime Minister: Despite his undertaking at Question Time last Friday, why is the Government accepting the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision to pay married rate welfare benefits to young girls under the age of consent who establish de facto relationships? How does the Prime Minister justify this policy which provides a financial inducement to young girls to leave home and establish an illegal de facto relationship and so become eligible for a welfare benefit?

—I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. He ought to agree-I hope he will-that this is both a sensitive and a technical area. What has happened, if I may inform the honourable member, is that the Government has arranged for legal officers of the Department of Social Security to discuss the amendment in question with leaders of the parties in the Senate--
—I have agreed to go to a briefing as well, but that does not answer the problem.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker is not entitled to ask a supplementary question.

—The honourable member for Barker can wag his head and, if that gives him satisfaction, let him keep on doing it. I am simply saying to him that what we have done is arranged for legal officers of the Department to discuss the amendment in question with the leaders of the parties in the Senate to see whether we can find a resolution to this problem, the nature and dimension of which I recognise. We are going about this in a sensible manner. It is not a matter for hysteria and I hope that, as a result of the discussions that are being held with the leaders of the parties in the Senate, such a resolution can be reached.

—I refer the Minister for Territories to reports on the front page of yesterday's Canberra Times about the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Is it true that Mr Clunies-Ross is being denied electricity? Is it also true that special provisions are being made for the Administrator's spouse to be present on Cocos at Commonwealth expense? Will Dr Williams be employed by the Commonwealth during that period? Is this contrary to normal practice in the employment of spouses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the articles in the Canberra Times, naturally, and I have also had reports of a program on 60 Minutes which presented the Clunies-Ross side of the argument. Both seem to be predicated on the basis that there is some campaign against Mr Clunies-Ross Junior to disadvantage him; that just is not true. The Opposition is quite obviously offended that a woman has been appointed to the position of Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and is pursuing a policy of discrimination against and vilification of that person. The facts are that, with respect to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and all other areas under my administration, we do not pursue any policy of preventing the spouses of Commonwealth employees from seeking employment in those areas provided that suitable employment for which they are qualified is available. In fact, some 70 per cent of spouses of administration employees on Cocos are currently employed by the Commonwealth, and I think that is something which should be accepted as being in the best interests of the families concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: The Cocos (Keeling) Islands are some 3,500 kilometres west of Darwin. They represent an area of 14 square kilometres. By any measure, they constitute an isolated area in which Australians serve for fairly long periods. It is a fact that Commonwealth employees, be they male or female, posted to such areas have an entitlement to be accompanied by their families at Commonwealth expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but not to give them jobs.
—Seventy per cent of them have jobs. The honourable gentleman has a fixation about having the Clunies-Ross empire reinstated on Cocos, and I do not know why.
—That is absurd.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Mayo will not argue with the Chair.
—That is absurd. What a thoroughly absurd and dishonest thing to say.
—The honourable member for Mayo will not argue with the Chair. He will heed the Chair. I call the Minister.

—With respect to the specific job which was offered to Dr Williams, which is a short term appointment to carry out work on the cataloguing and assessment of the environment, vegetation and fauna of the Cocos (Keeling) area, the job was advertised in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. No suitable person was available. It is also the Government's intention to appoint a conservator in order to protect the fragile infrastructure of the islands. Dr Williams, who is qualified to occupy the position and who has previously undertaken research work on those islands, has been engaged for six months. I might point out to honourable gentlemen opposite that Dr Williams has a perfect entitlement to be on the island at Commonwealth expense as the spouse of a Commonwealth employee. I think what is being suggested by the honourable member opposite is that it is improper that Dr Williams be engaged to undertake work on the islands but that it would be proper if he accompanied his wife to the island and then we appointed someone else, who may also wish to take his or her spouse, to do the work.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to electricity generation, when most of Home Island was acquired by the Commonwealth in 1978 the Minister at the time, Mr Ellicott, and the Fraser Government decided to establish a council to administer local government matters on Home Island, where the majority of the former serfs of the Clunies-Ross family lived. With the establishment of the council, the Clunies-Ross family, by agreement of both sides, was not subject to the authority of the council. The situation has not changed. Late last year Mr Clunies-Ross--

TALK.START.PARA: —I can see your point, Bob. You should have got rid of him.

—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo. If he keeps interjecting at the rate he is going, the Chair will deal with him. No member in this House has the right to continue to interject at will. I refer the honourable member to standing order 55. I call the Minister.

—Late last year Mr Clunies-Ross demanded that over 10 per cent of the total power supplies of the island be diverted to himself and his family. That power was not available from the generating capacity of the council. The Administrator loaned the Clunies-Ross family a generator to cover their power needs. I think it is fair to say to the House that what is in fact happening on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is that the frictions which occurred before the separation of the Clunies-Rosses from the administration of the island have been building up for some time and I would suggest that Mr Clunies-Ross Junior has a lot of blame to bear for that.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Transport aware that a member of the infamous Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has been charged in Melbourne for offensive behaviour for stripping naked publicly when approached by a Federal Customs officer for a routine search?
—What would you do?

—His name was not John Brown, that is for sure. Is the Minister also aware that the refusal by the Australian National Line to reinstate this union member has led to a picket line being set up by the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia refuse to cross? As this industrial action has led to over 300 lay-offs at Webb dock in Melbourne and a total paralysis in shipping to and from Tasmania, costing Tasmanian farmers and businesses millions of dollars, I ask the Minister: Will the Government condemn this irresponsible abuse of union power? What action, if any, has the Minister taken to ensure that shipping to and from Tasmania resumes immediately without further interruption?
—One could gather from the thrust of the way the question was asked that--

—The nature of the honourable member's question suggested that in some way he condoned the action taken by the employee concerned. Certainly we on this side of the House do not. The incident involved an employee behaving in a manner that was totally unacceptable. The management exercised its prerogative and, I understand, suspended the person concerned. He has since been charged. There have been discussions and negotiations. The matter has been before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It was heard on 30 April and it was recommended that arbitration take place between the two parties concerned. The ANL, as the employer, has indicated that it will accept any decision that comes from the arbitration in respect of the matter and, at this stage, little progress is being made. The matter is of great concern to the Government.
—It is to Tasmania.

—Just let me get to Tasmania. I have spoken with Mr Ferdie Foster of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association yesterday morning. He has outlined to me-and I have passed this information on to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations-the gravity of the situation. Certainly the Government deplores what has happened. It should not have happened. We have enough difficulty in trying to improve the reliability and competitiveness of our waterfront services and our trading performance generally without being saddled with an occurrence of this nature. The Government is of the view that there can be no explanation for the behaviour concerned. Still, arbitration procedures are under way, and I and my colleague the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations will be doing our level best to find a solution to the situation as quickly as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. At a time when our export markets are under siege as a result of the agricultural trade war between the United States and the European Economic Community, and in view of the recent escalation of tensions between the United States and Japan, what are Australian companies doing to expand our exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing to note about the problems confronting Australian companies, particularly in the manufacturing industry, is, of course, the devastation which they experienced under the policies of our predecessors. The wages policies, the exchange rate policies and, indeed, nearly 30 years of mad industry policies led to the decimation of many of our industries. Of course, this was at a time when the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. He was happy to pursue these policies. He was, of course, under the spell of the National Party of Australia. But, together they were prepared to see Australia exposed to the vulnerability of having our exports spread over far too few areas, commodities and products.

ANSWER.PARA: But, under the enlightened policies of this Government, I might say that there are now a number of Australian companies that are leading the fight back into export markets as far as Australia is concerned. I would like to give a couple of examples of some of these success stories. Hypercom, which is a company that manufactures data communications systems, has increased its exports by 400 per cent over the last two years. Those exports now represent 91 per cent of its turnover. Varian Techtron, a producer of high quality scientific instruments, now exports 85 per cent of its sales. Moving to another area, that of pet food, Uncle Ben's of Australia increased its exports to the Japanese market by 80 per cent, and this increase was achieved during the last 12 months.

Recently the Prime Minister and I were able to acknowledge the winning of a consultancy contract by MacDonald Wagner Pty Ltd for a $300m development in Argentina. Decor, which concentrates on product design, has secured increases in exports as high as 300 per cent over a three-month period. ADPRO, a manufacturer of video fire detection and security equipment, has got into the United States market-the first Australian company to do so-and it has seen a 300 per cent increase in its exports last year.

It is important that Australian manufacturing companies recognise the new opportunities which exist for them overseas. If we look at what has happened in the eight months to February, we see that manufactured exports have increased by 23 per cent compared with the same period last year. There has been an 87 per cent increase for motor vehicles, a 97 per cent increase for office equipment and automatic data processing equipment, 49 per cent for pumps and compressors, 28 per cent for electrical machinery and 36 per cent for cutlery and other household equipment.

The important thing about this is that, during that eight-month period that I referred to, manufactured exports totalled $5 billion, or 22 per cent of our merchandise exports. We now have to see the continuation of the consistently successful policies of this Government so that we can see a greater contribution to our exports being made by manufacturing companies and other companies, for instance, those in the services sector. What we do not want to see is the policies of this country handed back to the economic vandals opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister which, in its way, is supplementary to the question just asked of the Minister for Trade by the honourable member for Herbert. It relates to the Government's responsibilities in the area. Is the Prime Minister aware that, in the first four months of the current shipping year, 23 per cent of available work time at the Glebe Island and Newcastle grain terminals was lost due to industrial stoppages? Is he aware that the average throughput of grain per employee at the Sydney terminal is just 17,000 tonnes a year compared with between 80,000 to 120,000 tonnes a man in comparable American ports? In view of the Prime Minister's statement last year admitting the damaging economic effects of restrictive work practices, and recent reports of a new Government survey of foreign trade barriers to Australian industry, can the Prime Minister tell the House what action the Government has taken against restrictive work practices and, in particular, against frivolous industrial stoppages that are obviously doing so much damage to Australia's international credibility and, of course, destroying our international competitiveness?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable gentleman for his question. Let me say at the outset that the Government does not condone the practices that have applied at the points to which he referred and, through the relevant Ministers, we are doing all that we can in regard to particular circumstances as well as trying to improve the general environment. Let me make the point to the right honourable gentleman-and I hope he will accept the validity of what I am saying-that since we have been in office we have tried to bring in a new approach to industrial relations in this country, and I think he would have to accept that the aggregate statistics show that that approach has been outstandingly successful. There has been, in fact, during the period of this Government, more than a halving of industrial disputes in this country. That has not occurred by accident.

ANSWER.PARA: I think honourable members would have noticed in one of this morning's newspapers-I forget which one-a report of a more detailed study which has been undertaken by two academics at the Australian National University which, in a more detailed form, confirmed the veracity of that picture shown by the aggregate statistics. Having said that-and, on behalf of the Government, taking considerable pride in that more than halving of industrial disputation under this Government as against the confrontationist tactics of honourable members opposite-I accept that obviously there are still areas which are considerably less than satisfactory. Of course, I do take the point of the right honourable gentleman that when those disputes occur at points which can disrupt and disadvantage this country's exports in general-particularly, as I understand the situation, our primary exports-we ought to be concerned and we are.

The Government has a general structure of committees which are concerned with examining barriers to our export competitiveness. One of those committees is particularly concerned with examining and discussing with those involved how we can improve the situation on the waterfront. That is the way in which we need to go about this matter. We will not solve this problem by draconian legislation. I believe that we will gradually get to a situation at those points in which we can get a significant improvement in throughput. I am not at odds in any way with the right honourable gentleman in saying that the requirements of this country are that there should be an absolute minimum of disruption at our ports so that neither the country as a whole nor our primary producers in particular are disadvantaged by what are so often quite unnecessary and unjustifiable disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and concerns the `Buy Australian' campaign. Can the Prime Minister advise the House as to the response so far to the `Australian Made' campaign? Is the Prime Minister concerned about reports that imported products are being falsely labelled as made in Australia? Will the Prime Minister outline the reasons why consumers should be looking for, and suppliers should be using, the official `Australian Made' logo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. It is a further indication of the considerable interest which he has shown and which I have witnessed with him in his electorate. I am pleased to be able to say that since the campaign began in late August of last year more than 800 manufacturers have signed up for the right to display the official green and gold `Australian Made' logo. I am equally pleased to say that there is overwhelming evidence that Australian consumers are responding very positively to the campaign. The latest research available to us indicates that two-thirds of Australians are now buying Australian-made products `most of the time'. That represents a 50 per cent increase on the number indicated by the previous survey, conducted at the beginning of the campaign. I think the honourable member would agree that that is a very significant improvement attributable to the campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to the next part of the honourable gentleman's question. I am concerned about reports of instances where imported products are being falsely labelled as made in Australia. There is simply no doubt that the best way to guarantee that a product is a genuine Australian-made product is by means of the official green and gold kangaroo logo. This logo is a registered certification mark which can be used only under licence issued by the Advance Australia Foundation. Approved licensees in those circumstances have satisfied the Advance Australia Foundation that their product is made in Australia with a minimum local content of 75 per cent.

In response to the final part of the honourable gentleman's question, the great advantage of shoppers choosing products bearing the official logo is that they are helping their country by reducing our dependence on imports and-in the same way and obviously connected with it-by boosting Australian production and Australian jobs. In conclusion, I again say that this has been a highly successful campaign and I thank the honourable member for his continuing support of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that present in the gallery this afternoon is the Hon. Clyde Cameron, a former member of this House and a former Minister in the Whitlam Government. On behalf of the House, I bid him welcome.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I refer again to the Prime Minister's professed concern for the low income families of Australia, in particular the staggering 2.6 million Australians who now live below the poverty line. Can the Prime Minister explain to the House the principles of social justice involved in the position of single income families on half average weekly earnings who paid $9.35 tax per week under the Fraser Government, who now pay $15.50 tax per week under the Hawke Government and who, after the Keating tax reforms are implemented on 1 July, will be paying $16.46 tax per week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that I do not accept, without verification, any figures that come from the honourable member.
—Withdraw that. That is offensive.
—Why should I withdraw it?
—Order! The Prime Minister may not cast aspersions on another member of the House.

—Madam Speaker, I ask for your indulgence. Would you hear me on your observation? I do not have to go to the honesty or integrity of the honourable member to say that I will not accept figures that he puts forward. I am not going to his integrity.
—I accept the explanation.

—Thank you, Madam Speaker. This Government will stand on any platform, now or at any time between now and the election, if the honourable member wants a comparison of the record of this Government with the record of the Fraser-Howard Government. As far as the position of low income people in this country is concerned, we share what I accept is a very legitimate concern of the honourable member who asked the question. I am not in any sense saying that the honourable gentleman does not have a concern for low income people in this country. I accept that completely; I am not questioning it in any way whatsoever. What I am saying is that since we came to office two periods can be characterised in economic terms. The first was when we had to save this country from economic disaster that our predecessors had inflicted on us. The best thing that we could do-we said it would be the best thing we could do-was to get people back to work. I remind the honourable gentleman that the last 12 months of the Government of which he was a part saw an additional quarter of a million Australians thrown on to the unemployment scrap-heap. The best thing this Government could do for the people of Australia was to restore employment growth. I said that we would create half a million new jobs in our first three years of office, and a whole gaggle of honourable members opposite poured scorn upon us. In the restoration of employment growth-again I would think that the honourable member would share our pride in this matter-over three-quarters of a million Australians have now been put back into employment. That is the best thing we can do to start to restore the fortunes of the people in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: However, we did not leave the matter at that macroeconomic level. In those circumstances we had to bring down the very substantial Budget deficit which represented 5 per cent of gross domestic product. There would be very high interest rates if we did not bring it down, and the very people about whom the honourable gentleman is talking would be the ones who suffered most. As we went about the tough task of reducing the Budget deficit, we could not simply give widespread overall hand outs. What we have done-this has been particularly true in the last two years-is target assistance to those most in need.

By way of example for the honourable member in the area of welfare payments, I remind him of this fact: Under this Government the family income supplement and additional pension benefit have been increased by 70 per cent, and that action alone has assisted 447,000 low income families. I am trying to say to the honourable gentleman that in the context of having first of all to rescue this economy from the devastation inflicted upon it by our predecessors and in the situation in which we lost $9 billion in national economic capacity, we have sought to target special measures to those most in need. I can assure the honourable gentleman that those concerns will be uppermost, both in the May statement and in the Budget that we bring down later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody can understand why the increase--
—The honourable member is not entitled to ask a supplementary question.

—Being mindful of this Government's proven record on taxation reform, I ask the Treasurer whether he will inform the House of any alternative comprehensive tax reform proposals which have been proposed to the Government by any section of the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Government won office again after the last election the policy which the Prime Minister had put to the electorate was that we would have a national summit meeting on taxation reform. Many organisations were invited to attend that summit meeting and to put scenarios for the tax system, which, of course, were costed by both the Treasury and by the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Quite a number of very comprehensive tax reform proposals were put at that summit by many organisations in this country. After that summit, the Government brought down its tax reform package in September 1985. There were 20 very large changes to the tax system, all of which are now legislated, bar the Australia Card which, of course, was shamefully defeated at the hands of the Opposition parties in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: September 1985 was the time when the present Leader of the Opposition was elected to the office of Leader of the Opposition. At the time, because he was fresh in the office, he announced a few guiding principles on taxation and promised more hard detail some time later. But in saying that, he said he would reject all of our fairness measures-that is, the taxing of non-cash fringe benefits, the capital gains tax, the stopping of entertainment deductions and negative gearing. However, 18 months after the Government's package was released, we know less today about John Howard's tax policy than we knew then.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer will use the correct title.

—We know less today about the tax policy of the honourable member for Bennelong than we knew then. Of course, we witnessed last year the fumbling and stumbling around the entertainment and FBT issue. The Leader of the Opposition pretended he would tax these areas. There was a phoney debate about section 26 (e), which we all know could never have been applied. We finished 1986 no better off in terms of knowing where he stood on taxation. On 12 February, on the AM program, he stated:

ANSWER.PARA: The details of that policy are going to be released a lot sooner than many people imagine.
It is now May; that was said in February. Mr Elliott, the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party, said:

The point is that the Liberal Party ought to get out and enunciate its tax policy. It is a damn good policy. Now if you have a damn good policy, my own view is that you ought to have it out up front and defend it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, on a point of order: In 1973 a question was asked about statements of high-ranking members of the Liberal Party. That was ruled out of order on the basis that the Minister was not responsible for what a high-ranking member of the Liberal Party said. What the Treasurer seeks to do is to get a general dorothy dix question put to him, and by having that dorothy dix question put to him--

—There would be no dispute about that proposition. After having that dorothy dix question put to him, he then starts to examine matters that, on any view of relevance, have nothing to do with his portfolio. I would ask you to warn--
—The Chair is listening carefully to the Treasurer.
—Thank you. I would ask you to keep that in mind, Madam Speaker.
—Madam Speaker--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask that the honourable member for North Sydney withdraw that aspersion on the honourable member on this side who asked that question.
—I did not hear anything wrong with what the honourable member for North Sydney had to say.
—Mr Elliott has told us that there is a policy which he calls a good policy. On the Schildberger program last week the Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: We have a policy on tax. The only thing that is missing is the numbers.

He was implying that the policy has been put together. Elliott has obviously seen it. The Leader of the Opposition said he has it, but he does not have the numbers. What we want to know in the public interest is: Where is it? Where is this secret tax policy? What is the Leader of the Opposition afraid of? What is contained in this tax policy that has made him so afraid that he keeps it hidden and under wraps? What is contained in his tax policy? He wants to try to wait until the next election and, about two weeks from the poll, unwrap this grab bag for the rich and try to sneak under the line. Let me tell him this: We will squash him on the way. If he thinks he can have a secret tax policy which he keeps to himself, which contains handouts for the rich, and then try to sneak his way to a poll, we will squash him like a bug before he gets to the line.

We have heard lots of incantations from the other side of the House about policy, honesty and integrity. What about some leadership from the honourable member for Bennelong? What about a tax policy? What about letting the public and the Parliament know what the policies are on that side of the House? He has had the job for 18 months. The Government has had a public tax debate. The Government arranged for all of the interest groups to meet in this chamber and put their views. It published a White Paper and a tax statement. It has legislated on all of the information. It has had public debates. What is the Leader of the Opposition, with his secret tax policy, afraid of? John Elliott says that it is good. The Leader of the Opposition says that he has one, but the numbers are missing. What about putting some of the numbers together with some integrity and bringing the integrity and the numbers to the table?

I said yesterday, and I will say now, that the Government sits again for the economic test on 13 May, but on 14 May the Leader of the Opposition sits for the economic test. On the night of 14 May, the day after the Government's test, we will want to know about the fiscal numbers of the tax policies of the honourable member for Bennelong. We will want to know how he will fund the $16 billion of commitments he has made. We will want to know how those many people who rely on outlays would survive in a nation under the leadership of the honourable member for Bennelong, who says he has the policies but who is afraid at this stage to bring them publicly to the fore.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware that the Federal Secretary of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, Mr O'Toole, has directed that every member of the union must pay $40 to cover damages and costs to the union incurred in the Mudginberri dispute? I ask the Minister what protection can be offered to union members who refuse to pay money out of their pockets to cover their union leaders' blatant breach of the law? What protection will the Minister offer abattoir owners who refuse any request to deduct the money from employees' pay packets and send it to those same union bosses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the direction allegedly made by Mr O'Toole, but I accept the veracity of the Leader of the Opposition in this matter and that this is probably something that has happened. The Leader of the Opposition is a fervent supporter of the Trade Practices Act in relation to its application to trade unions. In the case of Mudginberri, of course, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union was hit with fines of, I think, a little over $100,000 but also compensatory damages of $1.7m. A union hit with damages of that kind, which obviously involve extremely large amounts of money, probably would not have the capacity to pay that money from its own resources. The Leader of the Opposition would seem to want to have it both ways. He wants to be able to penalise unions with extremely heavy damages-$1.7m is obviously a very large amount of money, let alone the $100,000 for penalties-and then say to the union that it cannot raise the money from its members. Where does he expect it to get the money to pay the damages? Where does he expect it to get the money from? Does he expect the money to materialise out of thin air? Obviously, if a union is the subject of very heavy penalties, it has to find the money from somewhere. I seemed to detect in the Leader of the Opposition's question the belief that the unions should not--
—Order! I just point out that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition-who is not listening to me although he should be-has been interjecting all through Question Time.
—It has all been helpful.
—I ask him to cease. Helpful or unhelpful, the Chair is asking for it to stop.

—The thrust of the question from the Leader of the Opposition apparently is that the unions should not pay. Is that what he really means-that they should not seek to raise money from their members and that they should refuse to pay the fine? If that is his position, at least I understand what he is putting; but I must say that it sits oddly with his fervent support of the Trade Practices Act and the pursuit of penalties against trade unions under that Act. The honourable member cannot have it both ways. He wants to have the Act applied to unions; all right. If this happens and they are hit with penalties, they will have to raise the money from somewhere. They will have to levy their members. If they cannot do that, they will not be able to pay the fine. Obviously, the position of the Leader of the Opposition is quite hopeless in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, if a company were fined in some way under the Trade Practices Act, the shareholders would be expected to pay through the profits of the company. The Leader of the Opposition would not be saying that the shareholders collectively should not pay. In the case of a trade union he is saying that the members should not pay. The position of the Leader of the Opposition in this matter is absolutely absurd. He cannot have it both ways, he is in a hopeless position, and this an absolute demonstration of his total incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What measures has the Government taken to deliver information and advisory services to businesses in the manufacturing and service industries? Is any special attention paid to small businesses which need assistance to grow and export, or Commonwealth Government assistance to industry mainly targeted to the larger firm?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cowan for her question. The Commonwealth Government has implemented, under the regime of Senator Button, a number of measures to assist the development of world competitive manufacturing and service firms. I think that history will indicate that the greatest single area of economic failure on the part of this spavined mob opposite is their total failure to redirect the nature of our economic base. They were always looking at firms which were inward looking, which were totally concerned with servicing the Australian market, and nothing else. They never came to grips at any time with the fact that the world market out there was changing, and changing against our advantage.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most recent of the new developments has been the setting up, in conjunction with the State governments, of a nationwide program to provide information and advice to industry. The program was called NIES-the National Industry Extension Services. NIES has been launched in all States as a one stop shop for advice to businesses on product innovation and development, management systems, process technology, design and quality. By phoning or calling in to an NIES State office, firms can be either assisted immediately or directed to the most appropriate expert adviser in the private or the public sector. The clientele for NIES will come mainly from the small business sector and from medium sized firms. Certainly, the Government's entire range of support and incentive programs is available to small business. The Government recognises that often the smaller enterprise has the capacity to be innovative and to be able to secure a niche in specialist markets overseas. The Government attaches high priority to assisting small businesses to become world class operations capable of competing effectively in Australia and overseas.

In addition to NIES, which incorporates all of the Government's initiatives, assistance and advisory programs, the States themselves operate specialist small business corporation bureaux which can then co-ordinate with NIES business offices, and take on referrals for small businesses which are in need of start-up and other advice particular for small enterprise needs. Then, at the last stage, NIES business offices also link into Austrade services, because products have to be taken out into the world economy, and export assistance measures. The new exporter scheme came into effect last year to help introduce smaller firms to exporting, and it is working.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the Prime Minister's reply to the right honourable member for New England and his indicated concern for the essential wheat exports of Australia, why are he and his Labor Government intending to introduce legislation in this House in an attempt to legislate to oppose the Queensland National Party Government's essential services and exports industrial legislation, which has become law in Queensland in an endeavour to maintain or even increase Australia's exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman who asked the question may believe what he is saying, but he would be the only member of the House who does. The legislation to which he refers was not introduced for any industrial relations purpose whatsoever. It is a political gimmick. It is part of the destabilising armoury that the Premier of Queensland is directing, I might say, not so much at the Labor Party in this country but at the poor wretches opposite. Nothing that he is doing at this time has anything to do with the intrinsic welfare of the State of Queensland. It is part of the attack by the Premier of Queensland upon the whole political system in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: We fortunately have the possibility of testing the approach of the Queensland Premier in the industrial relations area in the period since we have been in office. We have the opportunity of looking at the level of industrial disputation for the years 1983, 1984, 1985 and 1986. Comparing the Queensland position with that of Australia as a whole, the level of days lost per thousand employees in the State of Queensland is 13 per cent higher than the Australian average. So we can test over a period of four years the confrontationist approach of the Queensland Premier against the rest of Australia. Queenslanders are 13 per cent worse off because when the Queensland Premier approaches an industrial relations situation, it is not with a view to seeing what is best done to deal with the industrial relations problem-it is sheer confrontationist politics.

If we want to look more broadly, let me say to honourable members that the advice that we have from the Attorney-General is that the legislation to which the honourable member for Maranoa refers is in contravention of at least six international conventions to which this country is party.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all very well for honourable members opposite to pour scorn on international conventions of the International Labour Organisation. In the military or communist dictatorships of this world where we see some signs, as we did in Poland at the end of the 1970s, of the emergence of the right of free men and women to withdraw their labour, honourable members opposite immediately applaud those signs of the right of free men and women in those sorts of dictatorships to withdraw their labour and, in those circumstances, they are the first to invoke the international principles of freedom of association and of the right of working people to withdraw their labour.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members opposite have a singular clarity of vision when they look to those dictatorships and they say: `Yes, it is good to see that there will be something like Solidarity emerging, where there will be that single thing which most distinguishes democracies from dictatorships of the Left or the Right'. The thing which distinguishes democracies from communist or military dictatorships is the right of free men and women to withdraw their labour. Honourable members opposite were right to welcome the emergence of that right when we saw some flowering of it in Poland. Where they see it as a proper thing, where they see international conventions perhaps being applied and emerging in the dictatorships, they say: `Yes, that is a good thing'. But in this country where this fascist fellow in Queensland--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to have that remark withdrawn.
—Order! The honourable member is out of order. Does the honourable member have a point of order?
—Madam Speaker, has the Prime Minister withdrawn that remark?
—No, the Prime Minister did not withdraw.
—Madam Speaker, under the Standing Orders dealing with unparliamentary language I ask that the Prime Minister withdraw that remark.
—I point out to the honourable member for Maranoa that the Prime Minister was not referring to him.

—The language that I have used was brought most recently to my mind by the honourable member for Bruce who, on the 12.30 Report yesterday, was asked about certain developments which may affect him rather directly. He described these--

—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. It is always good to see the Prime Minister get diverted. Now he is going to talk about the honourable member for Bruce. He has been asked a question by the honourable member for Maranoa--
—Order! I point out to the honourable member for North Sydney that the Prime Minister was responding to a point of order raised by the honourable member for Maranoa.
—Madam Speaker, in that event it is not open to him, your having ruled upon the matter and having--

—Calm down, fellows. Madam Speaker, your having ruled on the matter and the Prime Minister then having proceeded, it is not for him to go to something else which has nothing to do with the question at all. If relevance is to mean anything you must make a judgment upon it and direct the Prime Minister to abide by that judgment.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.

—As I have said, my memory of this language was jolted by the observations of the honourable member for Bruce yesterday when he was talking about what is happening in conservative politics. He had some particular concern in his own area. His words were quite simple. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . their aim, I think, is undoubtedly to break the Liberal Party as it exists, as a mainstream conservative force, and replace it with something much further to the right of an extreme right neo-fascist nature.

I do not often find myself in agreement with the honourable member for Bruce but I must say that on this occasion I cannot find myself in disagreement in any shape or form. What I am saying in regard--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order.
—I point out to honourable members on my right that they are bringing the House into disorder with their antics. I ask them to assist the Chair and the House.
—Madam Speaker, I am interested to know whether you will demand that the Prime Minister get back to the point of my question.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Madam Speaker, you can see that the language that I have used is well justified. I have been informed-I find it extremely strange-that, in a matter of a few weeks, the Queensland Minister, Mr Lester, is going to the International Labour Organisation for the month of June. In other words, honourable members opposite want to have it both ways. They want to recognise the authority of the International Labour Organisation-an organisation which is respected around the world because of its tripartite composition which sets standards which we hope will enable other countries to encourage practices which will mark them as countries developing a situation which will be capable of respect. They do this by having these conventions which set down the sorts of standards which should characterise decent behaviour in industry in countries around the world. This legislation, which honourable members seek, of the Queensland Premier whom I have properly described is, as we are advised by the Attorney-General, in contravention of about half a dozen of those international conventions.

ANSWER.PARA: If honourable members opposite in that corner of the House want to have in Queensland the same standards as communist and military dictatorships, so be it. But I will tell them what will happen. The people of Australia will give honourable members the judgment which they should rightly give to this fascist type approach. Fortunately, the people of this country believe that, as far as Australia is concerned, we should be distinguished from communist and military dictatorships by giving the right to free men and women to withdraw their labour.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—The Sydney Morning Herald newspapers of yesterday's date and again of today's date carry reports of evidence given at a trial in Sydney relating to the well known Chris Jones-Eddie Azzopardi case. The newspapers report my name and that of my wife as being numbered amongst several others, including my State counterpart and the New South Wales Premier, as frequenting illegal casinos in Parramatta and other illegal acts. Like the New South Wales Premier, who yesterday denied any knowledge of the accusations, I now advise the House of my complete innocence in all these matters. I have never visited an illegal casino in Parramatta or in any other place. I deplore the accusations that have been levelled against me. I am confident that police investigations already launched into these lying accusations will clear not only my name by also the names of my wife and of other people named in these malicious statements. Furthermore, I assert that Robert Cummings, expelled member of the Australian Labor Party, should be charged with making malicious and misleading statements. I deplore the efforts of this person of ill repute to slur innocent people.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
Any your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free,Mr Hollis,Mr Hunt,Mr Lloyd and Ms Mayer.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, we the undersigned citizens call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and concessional card holders and cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Hawke Government.
The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That we strenuously object to the Government's decision to delete 45 commonly prescribed drugs (including analgesics, anti-histamines, cough mixtures and expectorants) from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme;

That we strenuously object to the Health Minister's assertion that the health problems for which these medications are prescribed (e.g. arthritis and allergic rhinitis) are ``relatively minor, self-limiting illnesses''.
That we beg the House to reconsider these deletions from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Hodges and Mr Wilson.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen,Mr McArthur,Ms McHugh and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity. In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner.
The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Griffiths and Mr Hollis.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-ser- vicewomen and their families because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's veterans.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to: Ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of veterans and their families.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Nehl and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID Card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation yet introduced, and that on all the evidence available, it will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject Labor's ID Card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayer's money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
And we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
